The **ileum** [/ˈɪliəm/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") is the
final section of the [small intestine](/wiki/Small_intestine "Small
intestine") in most [higher vertebrates](/wiki/Higher_vertebrates "Higher
vertebrates"), including [mammals](/wiki/Mammals "Mammals"),
[reptiles](/wiki/Reptiles "Reptiles"), and [birds](/wiki/Birds "Birds"). In
[fish](/wiki/Fish "Fish"), the divisions of the small intestine are not as
clear and the terms **posterior intestine** or **distal intestine** may be
used instead of ileum.[2]

The ileum follows the [duodenum](/wiki/Duodenum "Duodenum") and
[jejunum](/wiki/Jejunum "Jejunum") and is separated from the
[cecum](/wiki/Cecum "Cecum") by the [ileocecal valve](/wiki/Ileocecal_valve
"Ileocecal valve") (ICV). In humans, the ileum is about 2–4 m long, and the
[pH](/wiki/PH "PH") is usually between 7 and 8 (neutral or slightly alkaline).

_Ileum_ is derived from the Greek word _eilein_ , meaning "to twist up
tightly."[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ileum&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Structure")]

The ileum is the third and final part of the small intestine. It follows the
[jejunum](/wiki/Jejunum "Jejunum") and ends at the ileocecal junction, where
the [terminal](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/terminal "wiktionary:terminal")
ileum communicates with the [cecum](/wiki/Cecum "Cecum") of the large
intestine through the [ileocecal valve](/wiki/Ileocecal_valve "Ileocecal
valve"). The ileum, along with the jejunum, is suspended inside the
[mesentery](/wiki/Mesentery "Mesentery"), a [peritoneal](/wiki/Peritoneum
"Peritoneum") formation that carries the blood vessels supplying them (the
[superior mesenteric artery](/wiki/Superior_mesenteric_artery "Superior
mesenteric artery") and [vein](/wiki/Superior_mesenteric_vein "Superior
mesenteric vein")), lymphatic vessels and nerve fibers.[3]

There is no line of demarcation between the jejunum and the ileum. There are,
however, subtle differences between the two:[3]

  * The ileum has more fat inside the mesentery than the jejunum.
  * The diameter of its [lumen](/wiki/Lumen_\(anatomy\) "Lumen \(anatomy\)") is smaller and has thinner walls than the jejunum.
  * Its [circular folds](/wiki/Circular_folds "Circular folds") are smaller and absent in the terminal part of the ileum.
  * While the length of the intestinal tract contains [lymphoid tissue](/wiki/Lymphoid_tissue "Lymphoid tissue"), only the ileum has abundant [Peyer's patches](/wiki/Peyer%27s_patches "Peyer's patches"), unencapsulated [lymphoid nodules](/wiki/Lymphoid_nodule "Lymphoid nodule") that contain large numbers of [lymphocytes](/wiki/Lymphocyte "Lymphocyte") and other cells of the [immune system](/wiki/Immune_system "Immune system").

### Histology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ileum&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Histology")]

Main article: [Gastrointestinal wall](/wiki/Gastrointestinal_wall
"Gastrointestinal wall")

The four layers that make up the wall of the ileum are consistent with those
of the [gastrointestinal tract](/wiki/Human_gastrointestinal_tract "Human
gastrointestinal tract"). From the inner to the outer surface, these
are:[4]:589

  * A [mucous membrane](/wiki/Mucous_membrane "Mucous membrane"), itself formed by three different layers: 
    * A single layer of [tall cells](/wiki/Simple_columnar_epithelium "Simple columnar epithelium") that line the [lumen](/wiki/Lumen_\(anatomy\) "Lumen \(anatomy\)") of the organ. The [epithelium](/wiki/Epithelium "Epithelium") that forms the innermost part of the mucosa has five distinct types of cells that serve different purposes, these are: [enterocytes](/wiki/Enterocytes "Enterocytes") with [microvilli](/wiki/Microvilli "Microvilli"), which digest and absorb nutrients; [goblet cells](/wiki/Goblet_cell "Goblet cell"), which secrete [mucin](/wiki/Mucin "Mucin"), a substance that lubricates the wall of the organ; [Paneth cells](/wiki/Paneth_cell "Paneth cell"), most common in the terminal part of the ileum, are only found at the bottom of the [intestinal glands](/wiki/Intestinal_glands "Intestinal glands") and release antimicrobial substances such as [alpha defensins](/wiki/Alpha_defensin "Alpha defensin") and [lysozyme](/wiki/Lysozyme "Lysozyme");[5] [microfold cells](/wiki/Microfold_cells "Microfold cells"), which take up and transport [antigens](/wiki/Antigen "Antigen") from the lumen to lymphatic cells of the lamina propria; and [enteroendocrine cells](/wiki/Enteroendocrine_cell "Enteroendocrine cell"), which secrete [hormones](/wiki/Hormones "Hormones").
    * An underlying [lamina propria](/wiki/Lamina_propria "Lamina propria") composed of [loose connective tissue](/wiki/Loose_connective_tissue "Loose connective tissue") and containing [germinal centers](/wiki/Germinal_center "Germinal center") and large aggregates of lymphoid tissue called [Peyer's patches](/wiki/Peyer%27s_patches "Peyer's patches"), which are a distinctive feature of the ileum.[4]:589
    * A thin layer of [smooth muscle](/wiki/Smooth_muscle "Smooth muscle") called [muscularis mucosae](/wiki/Muscularis_mucosae "Muscularis mucosae").
  * A [submucosa](/wiki/Submucosa "Submucosa") formed by [dense irregular connective tissue](/wiki/Dense_irregular_connective_tissue "Dense irregular connective tissue") that carries the larger [blood vessels](/wiki/Blood_vessels "Blood vessels") and a nervous component called [submucosal plexus](/wiki/Submucosal_plexus "Submucosal plexus"), which is part of the [enteric nervous system](/wiki/Enteric_nervous_system "Enteric nervous system").
  * An [external muscular layer](/wiki/Muscularis_externa "Muscularis externa") formed by two layers of [smooth muscle](/wiki/Smooth_muscle "Smooth muscle") arranged in circular bundles in the inner layer and in longitudinal bundles in the outer layer. Between the two layers is the [myenteric plexus](/wiki/Myenteric_plexus "Myenteric plexus"), formed by nervous tissue and also a part of the [enteric nervous system](/wiki/Enteric_nervous_system "Enteric nervous system").
  * A [serosa](/wiki/Serosa "Serosa") composed of [mesothelium](/wiki/Mesothelium "Mesothelium"), a single layer of [flat cells](/wiki/Simple_squamous_epithelium "Simple squamous epithelium") with varying quantities of underlying [connective](/wiki/Connective_tissue "Connective tissue") and [adipose tissue](/wiki/Adipose_tissue "Adipose tissue"). This layer represents the [visceral peritoneum](/wiki/Peritoneum "Peritoneum") and is continuous with the [mesentery](/wiki/Mesentery "Mesentery").[4]:571

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Gut_wall.svg/309px-Gut_wall.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Gut_wall.svg)

General structure of the gut wall. Brunner's glands are not found in the
ileum, but are a distinctive feature of the [duodenum](/wiki/Duodenum
"Duodenum").

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Gobletcell.jpg/272px-Gobletcell.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gobletcell.jpg)

[Goblet cells](/wiki/Goblet_cell "Goblet cell") in the wall of an ileum vili.
At its sides, [enterocytes](/wiki/Enterocytes "Enterocytes") are visible over
a core of [lamina propria](/wiki/Lamina_propria "Lamina propria").

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Peyer%27s_patch_%28improved_color%29.jpg/240px-Peyer%27s_patch_%28improved_color%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Peyer%27s_patch_\(improved_color\).jpg)

patch") circled.

### Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ileum&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Development")]

The [small intestine](/wiki/Small_intestine "Small intestine") develops from
the [midgut](/wiki/Midgut "Midgut") of the [primitive gut
tube](/w/index.php?title=Primitive_gut_tube&action=edit&redlink=1 "Primitive
gut tube \(page does not exist\)").[6] By the fifth week of
[embryological](/wiki/Embryo "Embryo") life, the ileum begins to grow longer
at a very fast rate, forming a U-shaped fold called the [primary intestinal
loop](/w/index.php?title=Primary_intestinal_loop&action=edit&redlink=1
"Primary intestinal loop \(page does not exist\)"). The
[proximal](/wiki/Proximal "Proximal") half of this loop will form the ileum.
The loop grows so fast in length that it outgrows the abdomen and protrudes
through the [umbilicus](/wiki/Navel "Navel"). By week 10, the loop retracts
back into the abdomen. Between weeks six and ten the small intestine rotates
anticlockwise, as viewed from the front of the embryo. It rotates a further
180 degrees after it has moved back into the abdomen. This process creates the
twisted shape of the [large intestine](/wiki/Large_intestine "Large
intestine").[6]

In the [fetus](/wiki/Fetus "Fetus") the ileum is connected to the
[navel](/wiki/Navel "Navel") by the [vitelline duct](/wiki/Vitelline_duct
"Vitelline duct"). In roughly 2−4% of humans, this duct fails to close during
the first seven weeks after birth, leaving a remnant called [Meckel's
diverticulum](/wiki/Meckel%27s_diverticulum "Meckel's diverticulum").[7]

## Function[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ileum&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Function")]

The function of the ileum is mainly to absorb [vitamin B12](/wiki/Vitamin_B12
"Vitamin B12") and [bile salts](/wiki/Bile_salts "Bile salts") and whatever
products of digestion were not absorbed by the jejunum. The wall itself is
made up of folds, each of which has many tiny finger-like projections known as
[villi](/wiki/Intestinal_villus "Intestinal villus") on its surface. In turn,
the epithelial cells that line these villi possess even larger numbers of
[microvilli](/wiki/Microvilli "Microvilli"). Therefore, the ileum has an
extremely large surface area both for the [adsorption](/wiki/Adsorption
"Adsorption") (attachment) of [enzyme](/wiki/Enzyme "Enzyme") molecules and
for the [absorption](/wiki/Absorption_\(chemistry\) "Absorption
\(chemistry\)") of products of [digestion](/wiki/Digestion "Digestion"). The
DNES (diffuse neuroendocrine system) cells of the ileum secrete various
hormones (gastrin, secretin, cholecystokinin) into the blood. Cells in the
lining of the ileum secrete the [protease](/wiki/Protease "Protease") and
[carbohydrase](/wiki/Carbohydrase "Carbohydrase") enzymes responsible for the
final stages of [protein](/wiki/Protein "Protein") and
[carbohydrate](/wiki/Carbohydrate "Carbohydrate") digestion into the
[lumen](/wiki/Lumen_\(anatomy\) "Lumen \(anatomy\)") of the intestine. These
enzymes are present in the [cytoplasm](/wiki/Cytoplasm "Cytoplasm") of the
[epithelial cells](/wiki/Epithelial_cells "Epithelial cells").

The villi contain large numbers of capillaries that take the amino acids and
glucose produced by digestion to the [hepatic portal
vein](/wiki/Hepatic_portal_vein "Hepatic portal vein") and the liver.
[Lacteals](/wiki/Lacteals "Lacteals") are small lymph vessels, and are present
in villi. They absorb [fatty acid](/wiki/Fatty_acid "Fatty acid") and
[glycerol](/wiki/Glycerol "Glycerol"), the products of fat digestion. Layers
of circular and longitudinal [smooth muscle](/wiki/Smooth_muscle "Smooth
muscle") enable the [chyme](/wiki/Chyme "Chyme") (partly digested food and
water) to be pushed along the ileum by waves of muscle contractions called
[peristalsis](/wiki/Peristalsis "Peristalsis"). The remaining chyme is passed
to the [colon](/wiki/Colon_\(anatomy\) "Colon \(anatomy\)").

## Clinical significance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ileum&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Clinical significance")]

It is of importance in medicine as it can be affected in a number of
diseases,[8] including:

  * [Crohn's disease](/wiki/Crohn%27s_disease "Crohn's disease")
  * [Tuberculosis](/wiki/Tuberculosis "Tuberculosis")
  * [Lymphoma](/wiki/Lymphoma "Lymphoma")
  * [Neuroendocrine tumours](/wiki/Neuroendocrine_tumours "Neuroendocrine tumours") (carcinoid)

## Other animals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ileum&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Other animals")]

In veterinary anatomy, the ileum is distinguished from the jejunum by being
that portion of the jejunoileum that is connected to the [caecum](/wiki/Caecum
"Caecum") by the [ileocecal fold](/wiki/Ileocecal_fold "Ileocecal fold").

The ileum is the short terminal part of the small intestine and forms the
connection to the large intestine. It is suspended by the caudal part of the
mesentery (mesoileum) and is attached, in addition, to the cecum by the
ileocecal fold. The ileum terminates at the cecocolic junction of the large
intestine forming the ileal orifice. In the dog the ileal orifice is located
at the level of the first or second lumbar vertebra, in the ox in the level of
the fourth lumbar vertebrae, in the sheep and goat at the level of the caudal
point of the costal arch.[9] By active muscular contraction of the ileum, and
closure of the ileal opening as a result of engorgement, the ileum prevents
the backflow of ingesta and the equalization of pressure between jejunum and
the base of the cecum. Disturbance of this sensitive balance is not uncommon
and is one of the causes of colic in horses. During any intestinal surgery,
for instance, during appendectomy, distal 2 feet of ileum should be checked
for the presence of Meckel's diverticulum.

qa.question: where is the ileum located in the body
qa.answer: ['the final section of the small intestine']

nq_181131_9.Answer Analysis: The answer specifies that the ileum is the final section of the small intestine.
